pros:
I have worked at Midland Heart for just under a year. It's an organisation I have always been interested at working with after being in the housing sector for over a decade. 

I love working for MH! There are mountains of staff engagement opportunities, training, away days, lunch and learn sessions. There is always an event or celebration happening and way to network with colleagues. 

My department, Asset Management, has a fantastic 'grow your own culture' which has allowed me to complete a new, first in housing, qualification in the first year of employment. 

There are clear paths for career progression and we are encouraged as managers to support our staff to shadow, train and develop. The management are open, easy to approach and ideas are listened to. 

There are flexible working options, which are growing with the organisations plans for a more customer focussed approach. 

Although I haven't been with MH for a long time I have already mapped a career plan with them, taken advantage of benefits such as gym discounts and free samosas, been developed and had my confidence grow in leaps and bounds.
cons: The lack of parking can be frustrating but the management are flexible allowing staff to move cars when required.

review_title: Poor Management, Lots of re-structure, Losing its values
cons:
Midland Heart is going through significant change with re-structure in all parts of the company. Employees have to apply for own jobs & lots of uncertainty. Lots of employees have left due to this, looking for more stable organisation. Promotion to management role is good if 'your face fits' and not about your skills & experience. Most managers (team leaders & and higher) are very young, new to the role and doesn't really know how to manage a team or develop staff. If you make a complaint about manager's incompetencies these fell into deaf ears and nothing is done. Most employees here are too scared to say anything against management or make a complaint. Too many experienced employees have now left and Midland Heart is losing its values & culture. High turn over of staff. Communication/feedback by senior management is poor with regards to any changes within department.

- Total reward strategy has been reviewed with regards to sick pay and sickness (due to high levels of sickness in the organisation).

- In Care & Support, most employees are overworked but less valued.

There are lots of opportunities to develop - I have been through the internal leadership academy as well as courses relevant to my role and involvement in lots of different projects.  There are always lots of events/lunch and learns etc so there are lots of opportunities to get involved and receive corporate updates.  Flexible working is excellent here - I have been supported to find a work/life balance that suits my family and there isn't a culture of excessive hours. review_title: Great place to work if you are hardworking and want to make a difference
pros:
Ive worked at the company for 10 years now - started as a customer services adviser, now working in Assets Team and managing contracts. 
There have been plenty of opportunities for me to apply for jobs and develop my career within the company - and I have come across many senior managers who are more than happy to mentor and  to give someone with no experience but the right behaviours and attitudes a chance to show what they are capable of. 

There will be even more investment going forward into staff development and helping people reach their career goals.

The workforce is diverse - in our team we have men and women, older colleagues and also someone who is 20 so when looking for solutions, we are able to look at a problem from many different aspects; bring innovation and continue the good practice at the same time. 

There is also flexibility in my role in terms of working hours and agile working - as a working mum it is very important for me to feel that my manager is supporting my returning to work after maternity leave as much as he can and his understanding of my circumstances has made me feel appreciated and motivated to do my best.

For our hard work, this year we were all given an extra day off - 1st January - and a pay rise above 2018 inflation rate. I don't think there are many companies that are currently in a situation to award their employees this well.

If you are a person passionate about communities, there are many projects you can get involved in - and really help to support those in the greatest need.
I find it great to work for a company that changes people lives for better - it is very satisfying to go home after a long day at work and think ' I made a difference today'.
cons:
The pace is fast so may not suit everyone. There is a lot of reporting involved which could be more streamlined - it is getting much better though.
As everywhere, there aren't that many opportunities to develop your career once you reach middle management level.
